feed.title: IEEE University of Toronto Student Branch

entry.title: Hardware Certification Workshop
entry.content:
Join IEEE at the annual Hardware Certification Workshop to learn more about fundamental circuit design and to create your own circuitry projects! This event will give you hands-on experience with common circuits such as the H-bridge, and more advanced ones like speaker circuits. So, if you’re a first-year student looking to explore electronics, or if you’re a second-year student looking to get ahead on your design projects - be sure to come out! Best of all - you will receive your very own basic circuitry certification at the end of it all!

Link to getting your tickets on eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/hardware-certification-workshop-tickets-41552962028
entry.summary: Join IEEE at the annual Hardware Certification Workshop to learn more about fundamental circuit design and to create your own circuitry projects! This event will give you hands-on experience with common circuits such as the H-bridge, and more advanced ones like speaker circuits. So, if you're a first-year student looking to explore electronics, or if you're a second-year student looking to get ahead on your design projects - be sure to come out! Best of all - you will receive your very own basic circuitry certification at the end of it all!

entry.title: Ontario Power Generation Site Tour
entry.content:
Curious about how energy is produced? Considering working in the power industry in the future? Well, here’s your chance to learn more! Join us for a tour of Ontario Power Generation, Ontario’s largest energy provider. You will have the opportunity to hear about OPG’s projects, tour the site, and speak to representatives from OPG! (Also, we will be providing free lunch for everyone! )

GET YOUR TICKET AT: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/ontario-power-generation-site-tour-tickets-42211629119 **SIGN UP DEADLINE IS Sunday, 21th Jan!! Sign up now as tickets will sell out quick!

**PLEASE FILL OUT THIS FORM AFTER PURCHASING YOUR TICKET: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf4bE8JJR706R-6J-veELGdp1Thyy34GjCax7y4sijPJnqpfw/viewform?usp=sf_link#responses

Join us for a tour of Ontario Power Generation, Ontario's largest energy provider. You will have the opportunity to hear about OPG's projects, tour the site, and speak to representatives from OPG! (Also, we will be providing free lunch for everyone! ) GET YOUR TICKET HERE

entry.title: Grad Talks: Power Electronics and Control

link.title: Grad Talks: Power Electronics and Control

entry.content:
Power Electronics has evolved rapidly in the past 25 years due to the development of new power electronic devices and real-time control hardware and software. Professor Dawson will be talking about his research involving modeling and control of excimer pulsed lasers and control systems for electrochemical reactions. Come by to hear from the professor on topics in Power and Control!

Food and drinks provided!

Upcoming talks:

Naomi Matsuura Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology Tues 12-1pm, Nov 28 BA 2179

Francis Dawson Energy Systems Thur 12-1pm, Nov 30 HA 403
entry.summary: Power Electronics has evolved rapidly in the past 25 years due to the development of new power electronic devices and real-time control hardware and software. Professor Dawson will be talking about his research involving modeling and control of excimer pulsed lasers and control systems for electrochemical reactions. Come by to hear from the professor on topics in Power and Control!

entry.title: Grad Talks: Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology

link.title: Grad Talks: Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology

entry.content:
Professor Matsuura will be giving a talk on the Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology area! There are many interesting topics - one focus of her group is the design of new biomaterials that can be remotely activated using medical imaging sources for cancer imaging and therapy. These biomaterials can biomaterials be used with medical imaging to facilitate the minimally-invasive, image-guided, local and site-specific delivery of cancer therapies to tumours in vivo.

Come by to learn more! Pizza and drinks are provided!

Upcoming Grad Talks events:

Naomi Matsuura Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology Tues 12-1pm, Nov 28 BA 2179

Francis Dawson Energy Systems Thur 12-1pm, Nov 30 HA 403
entry.summary: Professor Matsuura will be giving a talk on the Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology area! There are many interesting topics - one focus of her group is the design of new biomaterials that can be remotely activated using medical imaging sources for cancer imaging and therapy. These biomaterials can biomaterials be used with medical imaging to facilitate the minimally-invasive, image-guided, local and site-specific delivery of cancer therapies to tumours in vivo.

entry.title: Grad Talks: Electromagnetics
entry.content:
Professor Sean Hum will be talking about the exciting research that is going on in the Electromagnetics Group in the ECE department at UofT! Research topics in advanced antennas for satellite communications, cloaking, wireless power transfer, computational electromagnetics, and electromagnetic metamaterials will be discussed. Faculty members will be introduced and ways to get involved with electromagnetics in both your coursework and other projects will be presented.

Learn more about Professor Hum here: http://www.waves.utoronto.ca/prof/svhum/

Food and drinks provided!

See below for full schedule of talks:

Deepa Kundur Communications Tues 12-1pm, Nov 21 BA 2179

Luca Scardovi Systems Control Thur 1-2 pm, Nov 23 SF 2202

Jason Anderson Computer Engineering Thur 6-7pm, Nov 23 BA 2155

Sean Hum Electromagnetics Fri 12-1pm, Nov 24 BA 2135

Naomi Matsuura Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology Tues 12-1pm, Nov 28 BA 2179

Francis Dawson Energy Systems Thur 12-1pm, Nov 30 HA 403
entry.summary: Professor Sean Hum will be talking about the exciting research that is going on in the Electromagnetics Group in the ECE department at UofT! Research topics in advanced antennas for satellite communications, cloaking, wireless power transfer, computational electromagnetics, and electromagnetic metamaterials will be discussed. Faculty members will be introduced and ways to get involved with electromagnetics in both your coursework and other projects will be presented.

entry.title: Grad Talks: Automatic Synthesis of Hardware from Software

link.title: Grad Talks: Automatic Synthesis of Hardware from Software

entry.content:
Professor Anderson’s research aims to allow software design methodologies to be used for hardware design; particularly, hardware as implemented on field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). FPGAs are programmable computer chips that can be configured in the field by the end user. Recently, FPGA chips have been deployed in cloud-computing environments, where they work alongside traditional processors to realize computations with better throughput and energy efficiency.

Learn more about Professor Anderson at: <www.eecg.toronto.edu/~janders>

Food and drinks provided!

See below for full schedule of talks:

Deepa Kundur Communications Tues 12-1pm, Nov 21 BA 2179

Luca Scardovi Systems Control Thur 1-2 pm, Nov 23 SF 2202

Jason Anderson Computer Engineering Thur 6-7pm, Nov 23 BA 2155

Sean Hum Electromagnetics Fri 12-1pm, Nov 24 BA 2135

Naomi Matsuura Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology Tues 12-1pm, Nov 28 BA 2179

Francis Dawson Energy Systems Thur 12-1pm, Nov 30 HA 403

FPGAs are programmable computer chips that can be configured in the field by the end user. entry.title: Grad Talks: Systems Control
entry.content:
Professor Luca Scardovi’s research focuses on complex interconnected systems, and methodologies to control and analyze emergent biological and engineered systems. Come to this session to learn more about research and graduate studies in the Systems Control area!

Learn more about Professor Scardovi at: http://scg.utoronto.ca/~scardovi/

Food and drinks provided!

See below for full schedule of talks:

Deepa Kundur Communications Tues 12-1pm, Nov 21 BA 2179

Luca Scardovi Systems Control Thur 1-2 pm, Nov 23 SF 2202

Jason Anderson Computer Engineering Thur 6-7pm, Nov 23 BA 2155

Sean Hum Electromagnetics Fri 12-1pm, Nov 24 BA 2135

Naomi Matsuura Nanotechnology, Molecular Imaging & Systems Biology Tues 12-1pm, Nov 28 BA 2179

Francis Dawson Energy Systems Thur 12-1pm, Nov 30 HA 403
entry.summary: Professor Luca Scardovi's research focuses on complex interconnected systems, and methodologies to control and analyze emergent biological and engineered systems. Come to this session to learn more about research and graduate studies in the Systems Control area!

entry.title: Grad Talks: Communications and Cyber Security

link.title: Grad Talks: Communications and Cyber Security

entry.content:
Professor Kundur’s research interests lie in cyber security, signal processing and complex dynamical networks. Come to this session to learn more about the communications area and doing grad studies in the communications group at UofT! You will also get the opportunity to learn about the various professors in the communications group and their research topics.

Learn more about Professor Kundur at http://www.comm.utoronto.ca/~dkundur/
entry.summary: Professor Kundur’s research interests lie in cyber security, signal processing and complex dynamical networks. Come to this session to learn more about the communications area and doing grad studies in the communications group at UofT! You will also get the opportunity to learn about the various professors in the communications group and their research topics.

entry.title: Tech News: Build an illuminated Halloween costume

link.title: Tech News: Build an illuminated Halloween costume

entry.content:
Tech News: Build an illuminated Halloween costume

Can you believe that September is almost over and October is right around the corner!!? Since preparing Halloween costume is probably the biggest excitement during October, why not try this illuminated costume by Adafruit?

The costume is generally built with the touching sensitive Gamma Mo Microcontrollers to perform the animation that’s pre-programmed in full color. These microcontroller which runs CircuitPython are easily embedded under wearable clothes. CircuitPython is the modified Python language specially for embedded devices. What makes this topic further interesting is that Python has not been categorized as embedded language like C/C++, but if this new CircuitPython begins to form the basis of Microcontroller programing, then the “normal” in coding world might be revolutionized in the future.

Finally, if you are interested in building one yourself, there is a full instruction in the original article as well!

Read the full article at IEEE Spectrum!
entry.summary: Can you believe that September is almost over and October is right around the corner!!? Since preparing Halloween costume is probably the biggest excitement during October, why not try this illuminated costume by Adafruit?

entry.title: Tech News: Stretchy, Waterproof Solar Cells to Power Wearables

link.title: Tech News: Stretchy, Waterproof Solar Cells to Power Wearables

entry.content:
Stretchy, Waterproof Solar Cells to Power Wearables

Organic solar cells could be sewn into clothes in the near future to power wearable devices. With a steady power supply, wearable devices such as health monitors will be able to continuously collect data. Previously, energy-harvesting textiles were difficult to make because they had to collect energy efficiently, be highly stretchable and be stable in air and water. However, researchers have developed flexible organic solar cells with a high energy conversion efficiency of 7.9 percent that decreased slightly after undergoing extensive water experiments. Further research will be focused on using other materials to improve performance.

Read the full article at IEEE Spectrum!
entry.summary: Organic solar cells could be sewn into clothes in the near future to power wearable devices.
